qas.question: What did Hume think our beliefs are?

answers.text: a result of accumulated habits, developed in response to accumulated sense experiences

qas.question: What did Hume think our beliefs can't be established solely by?
What did Hume think is a circular argument?
What did Hume say we can't know by inductive reasoning?

answers.text: that the sun will continue to rise in the East

qas.question: Why did Hume say we expect the sun to rise?

answers.text: because it has repeatedly done so in the past

plausible_answers.text: the future will resemble the past

qas.question: Why does Hume say we can know the sun will rise in the east?
What did problem of the scientific method did Hume solve?
Where does Hume say the sun sets?
Humes argues there is no way to know the past will be like what?

context: Hume maintained that all knowledge, even the most basic beliefs about the natural world, cannot be conclusively established by <a1_0>reason<a1_0/>. Rather, he maintained, our beliefs are more <a0_0>a result of accumulated habits, developed in response to accumulated sense experiences<a0_0/>. Among his many arguments Hume also added another important slant to the debate about scientific method — that of <b7_0>the problem of induction<b7_0/>. <b5_0>Hume<b5_0/> argued that it requires inductive reasoning to arrive at the premises for the principle of inductive reasoning, and therefore <a2_0>the justification for inductive reasoning<a2_0/> is a circular argument. Among Hume's conclusions regarding the problem of induction is that there is no certainty that <b6_0><b9_0>the future<b9_0/> will resemble the past<b6_0/>. Thus, as a simple instance posed by Hume, we cannot know with certainty by inductive reasoning <a3_0>that the sun will continue to rise in <b8_0>the East<b8_0/><a3_0/>, but instead come to expect it to do so <a4_0>because it has repeatedly done so in the past<a4_0/>.
